revision.comment: added [[Category:Films directed by Katja von Garnier]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Iron Jawed Angels | image = Iron Jawed Angels.jpg | caption = DVD cover | director = [[Katja von Garnier]] | producer = {{ubl|James Bigwood|Laura McCorkindale|Denise Pinckley}} | writer = {{ubl|Sally Robinson|Eugenia Bostwick-Singer|Raymond Singer|Jennifer Friedes}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Hilary Swank]]|[[Frances O'Connor]]|[[Julia Ormond]]|[[Anjelica Huston]]}} | music = {{ubl|[[Reinhold Heil]]|[[Johnny Klimek]]}} | cinematography = Robbie Greenberg | editing = Hans Funck | distributor = HBO Films | released = {{Film date|2004|1|16|[[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]|2004|2|15|United States}} | runtime = 125 minutes | country = United States | language = English | production companies = {{ubl|[[HBO Films]]|Blue Dominion Productions|Bluebird House|Spring Creek Productions}} }} '''''Iron Jawed Angels''''' is a 2004 American [[historical drama film]] directed by [[Katja von Garnier]]. The film stars [[Hilary Swank]] as suffragist leader [[Alice Paul]], [[Frances O'Connor]] as activist [[Lucy Burns]], [[Julia Ormond]] as [[Inez Milholland]], and [[Anjelica Huston]] as [[Carrie Chapman Catt]]. It received critical acclaim after the film premiered at the 2004 [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmmonthly.com/Behind/Articles/Sundance2004/Sundance2004.html|title=Interview with Paul Fischer at the Sundance Film Festival in 2004|website=Film Monthly}}</ref>
The film focuses on the [[Women's suffrage in the United States|American women's suffrage]] movement during the 1910s and follows women's suffrage leaders Alice Paul and Lucy Burns as they use peaceful and effective [[Nonviolence|nonviolent]] strategies, tactics, and dialogues to revolutionize the American feminist movement to grant women the right to vote. The film was released in the United States on February 15, 2004.
==Plot== [[Alice Paul]] and [[Lucy Burns]] return from England where they met while participating in the [[Women's Social and Political Union]] started by radical suffragette leader [[Emmeline Pankhurst]] and led by her daughter [[Christabel Pankhurst]]. The pair presents a plan to the [[National American Woman Suffrage Association|National American Woman's Suffrage Association]] (NAWSA) to campaign directly in Washington D.C. for national voting rights for women. They find that their ideas are too forceful for the established suffragette leaders, particularly [[Carrie Chapman Catt]], but they are allowed to lead the NAWSA Congressional Committee in D.C. They start by organizing the [[Woman Suffrage Parade of 1913|1913 Woman Suffrage Procession]] on the eve of President [[Woodrow Wilson]]'s inauguration.
While soliciting donations at an art gallery, Paul convinces labor lawyer [[Inez Milholland]] to lead the parade on a white horse. Paul also meets a Washington newspaper political cartoonist, Ben Weissman (a fictional character), and there are hints of romantic overtones. In a fictional scene, Paul tries to explain to [[Ida B. Wells]] why she wants African American women to march in the back of the parade in order to not anger southern Democrats and activists, but Wells refuses, and she comes out of the crowd to join a white group during the middle of the parade (Wells did refuse to be segregated, and marched with her state delegation, but never met with Paul about it.<ref>http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2226351</ref>). After disagreements over fundraising, Paul and Burns are forced out of the NAWSA, and they found the [[National Woman's Party]] (NWP) to support their approach. Alice Paul briefly explores a romantic relationship with Ben Weissman.
Further conflicts within the movement are portrayed as NAWSA leaders criticize NWP tactics, such as protesting against Wilson, and their sustained picketing outside of the White House in the [[Silent Sentinels]] action. Relations between the American government and the NWP protesters also intensify, as many women are arrested for their actions and charged with "obstructing traffic."
The arrested women are sent to the [[Lorton Reformatory|Occoquan Workhouse]] for 60-day terms. Despite [[Night of Terror (event)|abusive and terrorizing treatment]], Paul and other women undertake a [[hunger strike]], during which paid guards [[Force-feeding|force-feed]] them milk and raw eggs. The suffragists are blocked from seeing visitors or lawyers, until (fictional) [[U.S. Senator]] Tom Leighton visits his wife Emily, one of the imprisoned women. News of their treatment leaks to the media after Emily secretly passes a letter to her husband during his visit. Paul, Burns, and the other women are released.
Pressure continues to be put on President Wilson as the NAWSA joins in the NWP call for passage of the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. Wilson finally accedes to the pressure rather than be called out in the international press for fighting for democracy in Europe while denying democracy's benefits to half of the U.S. population. During the amendment's ratification, [[Harry T. Burn]], a member of the Tennessee legislature, receives a telegram from his mother at the last minute, changes his vote, and the amendment passes.
==Origin of title== The film derives its title from Massachusetts Representative [[Joseph Walsh (Massachusetts)|Joseph Walsh]], who in 1917 opposed the creation of a committee to deal with women's suffrage. Walsh thought the creation of a committee would be yielding to "the nagging of iron-jawed angels" and referred to the [[Silent Sentinels]] as "bewildered, deluded creatures with short skirts and short hair."<ref>{{cite web|title=HOUSE MOVES FOR WOMAN SUFFRAGE; Adopts by 181 to 107 Rule to Create a Committee to Deal with the Subject. DEBATE A HEATED ONE Annoyance of President by Pickets at White House Denounced as "Outlawry."|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1917/09/25/archives/house-moves-for-woman-suffrage-adopts-by-181-to-107-rule-to-create.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 25, 1917}}</ref> The use of steel holding open the jaws of the women being force-fed after the [[Silent Sentinel]] arrests and hunger strike is also a plot point in the film.
==Cast== * [[Hilary Swank]] as [[Alice Paul]] * [[Frances O'Connor]] as [[Lucy Burns]] * [[Molly Parker]] as Emily Leighton<ref name="verdict">{{cite web|first=Elizabeth|last=Skipper|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/ironjawedangels.php|title=Review of ''Iron-Jawed Angels''|website=DVD Verdict|date=November 1, 2004|quote=''I also noticed Molly Parker as the supporting character of Emily Leighton, a Senator's wife. Parker's character – a fabricated figure, we learn from the commentary.''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626151936/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/ironjawedangels.php|archivedate=June 26, 2015|df=}}</ref> * [[Laura Fraser]] as [[Doris Stevens]] * [[Lois Smith]] as Rev. Dr. [[Anna Howard Shaw]] * [[Vera Farmiga]] as [[Ruza Wenclawska]] * [[Brooke Smith (actress)|Brooke Smith]] as [[Mabel Vernon]] * [[Patrick Dempsey]] as Ben Weissman<ref name="verdict2">DVD Verdict: ''In this movie, Alice is given a fledgling romance with political cartoonist Ben Weissman. According to the audio commentary, he is another completely fictional character, created to give Alice a (sort of) love interest.''</ref> * [[Julia Ormond]] as [[Inez Milholland]] * Adilah Barnes as [[Ida Wells-Barnett]] * [[Anjelica Huston]] as [[Carrie Chapman Catt]] * [[Margo Martindale]] as [[Harriot Eaton Stanton Blatch]] * [[Bob Gunton]] as [[Woodrow Wilson]] * Vinny Genna as [[Fiorello La Guardia]] * Joseph Adams as Senator Thomas "Tom" Leighton * Brett Boseman as Ben Weissman's child
===Fictional characters=== Fictional characters in the film are Ben Weissman; his child; Emily Leighton; and Senator Tom Leighton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ironjawedangelsmediasmarts.blogspot.com/p/characters.html|title=Iron Jawed Angels: Characters|website=Iron Jawed Angels Media Smarts|accessdate=March 21, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/ironjawedangels.php|title=DVD Verdict Review – Iron Jawed Angels|website=DVD Verdict|date=November 1, 2004|accessdate=March 21, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626151936/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/ironjawedangels.php|archivedate=June 26, 2015|df=}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical response=== Film critic [[Richard Roeper]] gave the film a positive review, writing, "''Iron Jawed Angels'' is an important history lesson told in a fresh, and blazing fashion."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvplex.go.com/buenavista/ebertandroeper/mp3/040216_iron_jawed_angels.mp3|title=Iron Jawed Angels Review|website=TV Plex|date=February 17, 2004}}</ref> Scott Faundas of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a negative review, writing, "[[HBO]]'s starry suffragette drama, ''Iron Jawed Angels'', latches on to a worthy historical subject and then hopes noble intentions will be enough to carry the day. Alas, there's no such luck in this talky, melodramatic overview of the dawn of equal rights for women in America. Gussied up with a comically anachronistic use of period music on the soundtrack and flashy, [[MTV]]-style montage sequences, pic misguidedly strives – but ultimately fails – to belie its instincts as an assembly-line movie-of-the-week."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2004/film/reviews/iron-jawed-angels-1200536877/|title=Review: 'Iron Jawed Angels'|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=January 22, 2004}}</ref>
Robert Pardi of ''[[TV Guide]]'' gave a mixed review, "All the elements for a splendid film about the early days of the women's rights are in place, but director Katja von Garnier's use of distracting cinematic trickery and jarringly modern music meshes poorly with the period setting... Blessed with a flawless physical production, von Garnier distorts her epic tale with music that belongs on a [[Lilith Fair]] tour; it sometimes feels as though she and her writers conceived the fight for women's suffrage as a 1912 version of ''[[Sex and the City]]''. Only when the anachronisms finally subside in the film's final third is the moving core is allowed to shine."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movies.tvguide.com/iron-jawed-angels/review/278843|title=Iron Jawed Angels Review|website=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}</ref>
===Accolades=== The film was nominated for five awards at [[56th Primetime Emmy Awards]], none of which were won; three awards at the [[62nd Golden Globe Awards]], winning one; and two awards at the [[9th Golden Satellite Awards]], winning one. [[Anjelica Huston]] won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Series, Miniseries or Television Film]] and the [[Satellite Award for Best Supporting Actress – Series, Miniseries or Television Film]] for her performance in the film. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Result |- | rowspan="11"| 2004 | rowspan="5"| [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s | [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Casting for a Miniseries, Movie, or a Special|Outstanding Casting for a Miniseries, Movie, or a Special]] | Janet Hirshenson, Jane Jenkins, Liz Marks, Kathleen Chopin | {{nom}} |- | [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Cinematography for a Miniseries or Movie|Outstanding Cinematography for a Miniseries or a Movie]] | Robbie Greenberg | {{nom}} |- | [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Costumes for a Miniseries, Movie or a Special|Outstanding Costumes for a Miniseries, Movie, or a Special]] | Caroline Harris, Eric Van Wagoner, Carl Curnutte III | {{nom}} |- | [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie|Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie]] | [[Anjelica Huston]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Miniseries, Movie or a Dramatic Special|Outstanding Writing for a Miniseries, Movie, or a Dramatic Special]] | Sally Robinson, Eugenia Bostwick-Singer, Raymond Singer, Jennifer Friedes | {{nom}} |- | [[Casting Society of America]] | Best Casting for TV Movie revision.text:
{{Spanish name|Coixet|Castillo}} {{Infobox person | name = Isabel Coixet | image = Isabel Coixet - La Librería (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Isabel Coixet Castillo | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1960|4|9}} | birth_place = [[Sant Adrià del Besós]],[[Barcelona]], [[Spain]] | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | other_names = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Barcelona]] | occupation = Film director | years_active = 1989–present | known_for = ''[[My Life Without Me]]''
''[[The Secret Life of Words]]'' | notable_works = | website = http://misswasabi.com }} '''Isabel Coixet Castillo''' ({{IPA-ca|izəˈβɛl kuˈʃɛt}}; born 9 April 1960) is a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[film director]]. She is one of the most prolific film directors of contemporary [[Spain]], having directed twelve feature-length films since the beginning of her film career in 1988, in addition to documentary films, shorts, and commercials. Her films follow a departure from traditional national [[cinema of Spain]], and help to “untangle films from their national context, ... clearing the path for thinking about national film from different perspectives.”{{cite book|last=Pavlovic|first=Tatjana|title=100 Years of Spanish Cinema|year=2009|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell Publishing|isbn=978-1-4051-8420-5|pages=181–225}} The recurring themes of “emotions, feelings, and existential conflict” coupled with her distinct visual style secure the “multifaceted (she directs, writes, produces, and acts)” filmmaker's status as a “[[Catalans|Catalan]] [[auteur]]”.{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Paul Julian|title=Waiting for Pedro|journal=Sight and Sound|date=January 2004|volume=14|issue=1|pages=9–9}} == Early Life == Isabel Coixet (Sant Adrià del Besós, Barcelona, April, 9 of 1960) started filming when she was given a 8mm camera on the occasion of her First Communion. After obtaining a BA degree in History at Barcelona University, where she majored in Eighteenth and Nineteenth Century History, she worked in advertising and spot writing with a magazine called ''Fotogramas''. She continued working in the world of advertising, gaining a brillian curriculum in that field, standing out as creative director of the agency JWT.{{Cite web|url=https://festivaldemalaga.com/noticias/ver/550/isabel-coixet-premio-retrospectiva-malaga-hoy-del-18-festival|title=Oficial Malaga Film Festival Webpage|last=|first=|date=|website=Festival de Malaga|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Her illustrious client list includes BMW, Renault and Ikea. She won several accolades for her spots, but the ads did not fulfilled her expectations. Coixet made her first short film in 1984 “''Mira y verás''”. {{Cite web|url=https://www.guiadelocio.com/cine/personajes/isabel-coixet|title=Guía del Ocio|last=|first=|date=|website=Guía del Ocio|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == Career == In 1988, Coixet made her debut as a scriptwriter and director in ''Demasiado Viejo Para Morir Joven'' ("Too Old to Die Young"). For this movie, she was nominated at the [[Goya Awards]] as a Best New Director. In 1996, she traveled to the United States to shoot his first English-language feature film entitled ''Things I Never Told You'' (''Cosas que nunca te dije''). In this moving drama, the cast was made up of American actors led by Lili Taylor and Andrew McCarthy. Coixet received her second nomination at the Goya Awards for [[Goya Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]]. Coixet then made an association with a French production company and in 1998 she shooted for the first time in Spain and in Spanish to carry out the historical adventure ''A los que aman''. Two years later she founded her own production company, with which she produced her most acclaimed film to date, Mi vida sin mí (My Life Without Me). Since then she has been one of the most acclaimed directors of our cinema. In 2000, she founded her own production company called [http://misswasabi.com Miss Wasabi Films], for which she has produced over 400 commercials. Her international success came in 2003 thanks to the intimate drama ''My Life Without Me''. The film is based on a short story by Nancy Kincaid in which the Canadian actress Sarah Polley played Ann, a young mother who decides to hide from her family that she has terminal cancer. This Hispanic-Canadian co-production was highly praised at the Berlin International Film Festival.{{Cite web|url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2003/02_programm_2003/02_Filmdatenblatt_2003_20030081.html#tab=boulevard|title=My Life Without Me {{!}} Mein Leben ohne mich|last=|first=|date=|website=www.berlinale.de|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-16}} Coixet then continued working with Polley on a new film, ''The Secret Life of Words'' which was released in 2005, starring Sarah Polley, Tim Robbins and Javier Cámara. The film was awarded with four Goyas: Best Film, Best Director, Best Production and Best Screenplay. In 2005, Coixet joined eighteen other international filmmakers, among them Gus Van Sant, Walter Salles and Joel and Ethan Cohen, to make the groundbreaking collective project "Paris, je t’aime",in which each director explored a different Paris quarter. Coixet has also made prominent documentaries on major themes such as ''Invisibles'', which was selected for the "Panorama" section of the 2007 Berlin Film Festival, about the international medical organization Doctors Without Borders. Also the documentary ''Journey'' ''To The Heart of Torture'' which was filmed in Sarajevo during the Balkan War and won an award at the October 2003 Human Rights Film Festival. In April 2006 she was honored with the Creu de San Jordi De Cine Awards, by the Generalitat de Catalunya. The Barcelona director received no less than two awards. In addition to the critical award for her latest film, ''The Secret Life of Words'' (La vida secreta de las palabras), as the best Spanish film, she also received the Rosa de Sant Jordi prize, which is voted by the public of Radio Nacional de España (RNE), for the best production. The award ceremony was held at the Palau de la Música.{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/diario/2006/04/26/catalunya/1146013656_850215.html|title=Isabel Coixet se convierte en la gran triunfadora de los Sant Jordi de cine|last=País|first=Ediciones El|date=2006-04-26|work=El País|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es|issn=1134-6582}} In 2008 Coixet released ''Elegy'', which was filmed in Vancouver and produced by Lakeshore Entertainment. The film was based on Philip Roth's novel The dying animal, written by Nicholas Meyer and starring Penelope Cruz and Ben Kingsley. ''Elegy'' was presented at the 58th Berlin International Film Festival.{{Cite web|url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2008/02_programm_2008/02_Filmdatenblatt_2008_20080020.html#tab=filmStills|title=Elegy|website=www.berlinale.de|access-date=2018-11-16}} In 2009, in the official selection of the Cannes Film Festival, she premiered the film ''Map of the Sounds of Tokyo'', shot between Japan and Barcelona and starring Rinko Kikuchi, Sergi López and Min Tanaka, with a script by Isabel Coixet herself. The same year she inaugurates ''From I to'' at the Centre D'Art Santa Mònica, an installation in honor of the work of John Berger. The same year she received the Gold Medal for Fine Arts and was also part of the jury of the 59th edition of the Berlin Film Festival. In April 2009 at the Centre d'Arts Santa Mónica in Barcelona and in April 2010 at La Casa Encendida in Madrid, Coixet presented a monographic exhibition dedicated to the British writer, art critic, poet and artist John Berger entitled "''From I to J. A tribute by Isabel Coixet to John Berger",'' with the collaboration of the architect Benedetta Tagliabue and the participation of the actresses Penélope Cruz, Monica Bellucci, Isabelle Huppert, Maria de Medeiros, Sarah Polley, Tilda Swinton and Leonor Watling.{{Cite news|url=https://www.europapress.es/nacional/noticia-isabel-coixet-recrea-universo-escritor-john-berger-le-hace-homenaje-20100212112237.html|title=Isabel Coixet recrea el universo del escritor John Berger y le hace un homenaje|last=|first=|date=2010-02-12|work=europapress.es|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}} Also in 2009 she directed a short documentary called "''La mujer es cosa de hombres''" about male violence and the media.{{Citation|title=50 años de... La mujer, cosa de hombres (TV) (2009)|url=https://www.filmaffinity.com/es/film161232.html|language=es|access-date=2018-11-16}} For a project entitled "50 years of..." about the history of Catalonia. In 2010, she took on the content in one of the three Spanish Pavilion lounges for the Expo Shangai. Plus, she inaugurates the exhibition "''Aral. The Lost Sea''", which shows her documentary with the same title, shot in Uzbekistan in 2009. {{Cite news|url=http://diariodesign.com/2011/03/el-documental-aral-el-mar-perdido-de-isabel-coixet-vuelve-al-roca-barcelona-gallery/|title=El documental 'Aral. El mar perdido' de Isabel Coixet, vuelve al Roca Barcelona Gallery - diariodesign.com|date=2011-03-16|work=diariodesign.com|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.lavanguardia.com/internacional/20100501/53919484919/china-muestra-a-un-publico-multitudinario-su-expo-en-shanghai.html|title=China muestra a un público multitudinario su Expo en Shanghai|work=La Vanguardia|access-date=2018-11-16}} In 2011, within the "Berlinale Specials" section of the Berlin Film Festival, she premieres the documentary “''Listening to Judge Garzón''” giving voice to the Spanish magistrate through an interview with writer Manuel Rivas. The film won the Goya in the Best Documentary category.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fotogramas.es/noticias-cine/a434666/coixet-presenta-el-documental-sobre-garzon/|title=Coixet presenta el documental sobre Garzón|date=2011-02-15|work=Fotogramas|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}} During 2012 she directs a documentary about the 10 years of the Prestige disaster and the volunteers who participated in the recovery of the Galician coasts under the title ''White Tide''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2012/05/17/natura/1337254986.html|title=Isabel Coixet: 'Ahora tenemos 50 'Prestige' a la vez'|last=Internet|first=Unidad Editorial|access-date=2018-11-16}} That same year, Coixet shot and produced her new project, ''Ayer no termina nunca'' (''Yesterday Never Ends'') which premiered in the Panorama Section of the 63rd edition of the International Film Festival of Berlin. As well as opening the Málaga Film Festival the same year where the film wins four Silver Biznagas in the categories, Special Jury Prize, Best Actress, Best Photography and Best Editing, the last two prizes won by Jordi Azategui.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ecartelera.com/noticias/13616/palmares-festival-malaga-2013/|title=Palmarés del Festival de Málaga 2013: '15 años y un día' y 'Ayer no termina nunca' salen triunfadoras|work=eCartelera|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es}} In the end of 2012 she also starts shooting a new project, which she finished in 2013, called ''Another Me'', a thriller English production written and directed by Coixet with a cast that featured Sophie Turner, Rhys Iphans, Johnatan Rhys Meyers and Geraldine Chaplin, among others.{{Citation|title=Another Me|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1816608/|access-date=2018-11-16}} In the summer of 2013 she started shooting [[Learning to Drive (film)|Learning to Drive]] an American production developed in [[New York City]], based on an article published in the New York Times and starring Sir [[Ben Kingsley]] and [[Patricia Clarkson]], with whom Isabel Coixet had already worked in Elegy. It premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] and won the Grolsch People's Choice Award.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thewrap.com/the-imitation-game-wins-toronto-audience-award/|title='The Imitation Game' Wins Toronto Audience Award|date=2014-09-14|work=TheWrap|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en-US}} ''Nobody Wants The Night'' was her next project, filmed in Norway, Bulgaria and the Canary Islands. The film starred Juliette Binoche, Rinko Kikuchi and Gabriel Byrne. The film opened the 66th Berlin International Film Festival to competition.{{Cite web|url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2015/02_programm_2015/02_Filmdatenblatt_2015_201510869.html#tab=filmStills|title=Nadie quiere la noche {{!}} Nobody Wants the Night|website=www.berlinale.de|access-date=2018-11-16}} Isabel Coixet, is always interested in shooting documentaries to denounce what she doesn't agree with or to give voice to her protagonists. She shoots a documentary in Chad at the end of 2014 narrated by Juliette Binoche entitled ''Talking about Rose''. ''Prisoner of Hissène Habré''. The piece relates the experience of a group of torture victims in their struggle to bring the former Chadian dictator to justice, an effort led by US human rights lawyer Reed Brody.{{Cite news|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/cultura/20150529/54431967428/isabel-coixet-calienta-el-juicio-contra-hissene-habre-con-la-historia-de-rose.html|title=Isabel Coixet calienta el juicio contra Hisséne Habré con la historia de Rose|work=La Vanguardia|access-date=2018-11-16}} During the 2015 edition of the Malaga Festival, the prize was awarded to her entire career and it was presented a retrospective documentary of her work, commissioned by the Festival itself, ''Words, Maps, Secrets And Other Things'', directed by Elena Trapé.{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/cultura/2015/04/24/actualidad/1429897007_181914.html|title=Isabel Coixet recibe en Málaga el premio a toda su carrera|last=García|first=Rocío|date=2015-04-24|work=El País|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es|issn=1134-6582}} Also in 2015 she received the recognized prize of the French Ministry of Culture of Knight of Arts and Letters.{{Cite news|url=https://www.efe.com/efe/espana/cultura/isabel-coixet-recibe-la-medalla-de-caballero-orden-las-artes-y-letras-francia/10005-2711921|title=Isabel Coixet recibe la medalla de Caballero de la Orden de las Artes y las Letras de Francia|work=www.efe.com|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es}} During 2015 and 2016, Isabel Coixet directs the project “''Spain in a Day”'', the Spanish version of the documentary crowdsourcing project produced by Mediapro. The project aims to portray the reality of a country reflected by hundreds of domestic videos recorded during the same day and that has had as direct precedents Britain in a Day and Italy in a Day. In the case of ''Spain in a Day'', the videos were recorded on 24 October 2015 by thousands of volunteers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.20minutos.es/noticia/2589516/0/spain-in-a-day/isabel-coixet/|title='Spain in a day', el proyecto de Isabel Coixet, recibe más de 5.200 vídeos en sólo 48 horas|last=20Minutos|work=20minutos.es - Últimas Noticias|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es}} In the summer of 2016 she directed the feature film ''The Bookshop'' (La librería). The script adapted by Coixet was based on the novel of the same name by the English writer Penelope Fitzgerald and received the prize for the best literary adaptation at the Frankfurt Book Fair in 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.buchmesse.de/fbmsite/en/fbf/press/press-releases/03268/|title=Frankfurter Buchmesse prize for Best International Literary Adaptation 2017|website=www.buchmesse.de|language=en|access-date=2018-11-16}} The film was shot in Northern Ireland and Barcelona, starring Emily Mortimer, Bill Nighy and Patricia Clarkson.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ewawomen.com/interviews/en-events-interviewing-ewa-president-isabel-coixet-html/|title=Interview with EWA president Isabel Coixet - EWA Women|date=2014-01-13|work=EWA Women|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en-US}} ''The Bookshop'' inaugurated the SEMINCI 2017, as a world premiere, receiving good reviews and it was commercially released in Spain on November 10, with a very positive critical reception and great public success.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fotogramas.es/noticias-cine/a19449215/la-libreria-isabel-coixet/|title='La librería', de Isabel Coixet: La vida secreta de las palabras|date=2017-10-20|work=Fotogramas|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}} {{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/cultura/2017/10/27/actualidad/1509108510_403105.html|title=Así es ‘La librería’ de Isabel Coixet|last=País|first=El|date=2017-10-27|work=El País|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es|issn=1134-6582}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.elblogdecineespanol.com/?p=38279|title="LA LIBRERÍA", DE ISABEL COIXET, DA LA SORPRESA EN LA TAQUILLA ESPAÑOLA {{!}} El Blog de Cine Español|website=www.elblogdecineespanol.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-16}} The Bookshop was premiered outside Spain in a "Berlinale Special Gala" at the 68th edition of the Berlin International Film Festival, which took place in February 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/das_festival/sektionen_sonderveranstaltungen/berlinale_special/index.html|title=Berlinale Special & Berlinale Series|website=www.berlinale.de|access-date=2018-11-16}} === Upcoming Projects === Coixet is now working in a collaboration with Netflix in her new film called “''Elisa y Marcela''” focused on the first registered gay marriage in Spain. The film will be the third original Spanish film by Netflix. It will be released in the 190 countries where Netflix operates in 2019.{{Cite news|url=https://www.20minutos.es/noticia/3333778/0/isabel-coixet-alia-netflix-nueva-pelicula-elisa-marcela/|title=Isabel Coixet se alía con Netflix para su nueva película, 'Elisa y Marcela'|last=20Minutos|work=20minutos.es - Últimas Noticias|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es}} === Productions === Isabel Coixet created her own production company in 2000, [http://misswasabi.com/ Miss Wasabi], with the vocation to self-produce her own more personal projects. The production company has dedicated itself basically to advertising, the making of video clips, documentaries and a fictional feature film, but also to projects outside the audiovisual sector, such as exhibitions, books and other types of cultural projects. Among the main projects, directed and produced by Isabel Coixet, are the documentary '''Aral, el mar perdido''' (2009), '''From I to J''' (2010), '''Escuchando al Juez Garzón''' (2011), the feature film '''Ayer no termina nunca''' (2013), or "''Talking about Rose. Prisoner of Hissène Habré''" (2015).{{Cite news|url=https://www.audiovisual451.com/miss-wasabi-films-la-productora-de-isabel-coixet-coproduce-varios-filmes-dirigidos-por-mujeres/|title=Miss Wasabi Films, la productora de Isabel Coixet, coproduce varios filmes dirigidos por mujeres|date=2015-11-24|work=Audiovisual451|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}} === 50 años de... === On the occasion of the celebration of the 50th anniversary of TVE Catalunya (TVE Cataluña) Isabel Coixet, along with fifteen other Catalan documentary filmmakers, had the idea of capturing in images, taken from the archive of Televisión Española, the last half Spanish century. The programme ''50 years of...'' (50 años de…) is in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of the first TVE broadcast in Catalonia, whose first headquarters was the mythical Miramar Hotel in Barcelona, which was maintained for twenty-four years, until 1983, when the production center was moved to San Cugat del Vallés. There has been a second season, as well as a third entitled ''Cómo hemos cambiado''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rtve.es/television/20090817/anos/289219.shtml|title=50 años de... {{!}} La evolución de la sociedad española, en 16 capítulos (temporada 2009) - RTVE.es|date=2009-08-17|work=RTVE.es|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}}{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100403211441/|title=Wayback Machine|website=web.archive.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-16}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.rtve.es/television/20091228/evolucion-sociedad-espanola-segunda-temporada/308382.shtml|title=50 años de... {{!}} La evolución de la sociedad española (segunda temporada) - RTVE.es|date=2009-12-28|work=RTVE.es|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}} ==Personal life and Political Views== Coixet was first released in the cinema almost at the same time as she released in maternity. Her daughter, Zoe, was born in 1997, a year after the release of her first feature, ''Things I Never Told You''. With her and her husband, DJ and musician César Sala, she formed a home in Barcelona, from where she has no problem sharing her opinions on the debate around the Catalan secession. This is not surprising, given that she has always shown that she has a marked political profile (her steps in advertising have led her to create campaign spots for the Spanish party PSOE).{{Cite news|url=https://www.elmundo.es/album/loc/2016/02/02/56b0e5b4268e3ee8698b46a9.html|title=El lado más íntimo de los candidatos a Mejor Director en los Premios Goya 2016 - Isabel Coixet se licenció en H... {{!}} loc {{!}} EL MUNDO|work=ELMUNDO|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es}} == Style and Themes == Coixet's work as a director is striking for being, as ''The New York Times'' describes her, “unclassifiable.”{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/29/arts/29iht-coixet29.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=Isabel Coixet, an 'Unclassifiable' Director|last1=Minder|first1=Raphael|date=28 September 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=6 February 2015}} Depending on the film, she shoots in English or Spanish, and subjects are diverse. Coixet’s trademark is her filmmaking technique, which was derived from her background in advertising, where visuals, color, and composition are carefully constructed. She works as the camera operator on all of her films. Among her most recurrent themes we can find a concern for communication, for words as a way of conventional understanding between people and that usually do not have the effect we expect. As she herself has acknowledged on occasion, she is obsessed with those situations in which messages do not reach their recipient. Another of her signs of identity is her marked social commitment, both with themes such as global warming (which she showed in 'The Secret Life of Words') and with social themes (documentaries such as the one made to Judge Garzón are a good example). Love and solitude are also constant in her cinema, in a very deep and spiritual way, nothing topical and stereotyped, although there is a common place recognizable in several of her productions that is the laundry. The filmmaker's approach to her characters and their stories is surprising because of her ability to get them in deep. To offer them to the spectator with a simple but tremendously transparent view. This search for connection is influenced by one of her great referents: the poet John Berger, from whom she draws, in his own words, the conviction that "anything can explain the world" through the connection between poetry, philosophy, etc. In Coixet's universe, spiritual connections between people are combined with a strong social consciousness, always ready to denounce the injustices of the world. In addition, Isabel Coixet's political and feminist involvement is evident. For example, ''The Secret Life of Words'' is a film that denounces the rape of a certain woman in a certain conflict: the Balkan War.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fotogramas.es/noticias-cine/a18626003/isabel-coixet-para-principiantes/|title=Isabel Coixet para principiantes|date=2017-04-09|work=Fotogramas|access-date=2018-11-16|language=es-ES}} == Filmography == *2017 ''[[The Bookshop (film)|The Bookshop]] *2016 ''[[:es:Un_corazón_roto_no_es_como_un_jarrón_roto_o_un_florero|Un Corazón roto no es como un jarrón roto o un florero]] (shortfilm)'' *2016 ''[[Spain in a Day]]'' *2015 ''[[Nobody Wants the Night]]'' (Nadie quiere la noche) *2015 ''[[Talking about Rose]]'', a documentary film about the life of [[Rose Lokissim]] *2014 ''[[Learning to Drive (film)|Learning to Drive]]'' *2013 ''[[Another Me (film)|Another Me]]'' (Mi otro yo) (working title: Panda Eyes) *2013 ''[[Yesterday Never Ends]]'' (Ayer no termina nunca) *2012 ''[[White Tide]]'' (Marea Blanca) *2011 ''[[Listening to Judge Garzón]]'' (Escuchando al Juez Garzón) *2010 ''[[Aral. The Lost Sea]]'' (Aral. El mar perdido) *2009 ''[[Map of the Sounds of Tokyo]]'' (Mapa de los sonidos de Tokio) *2008 ''[[Elegy (film)|Elegy]]'' *2007 ''[[Invisibles: A letter to Nora]]'' (Invisibles: Cartas a Nora) *2006 ''[[Paris, je t'aime|París je t’aime: Bastille]]'' *2005 ''[[The Secret Life of Words]]'' (La vida secreta de las palabras) *2004 ''[[Hay motivo!: La insoportable levedad del carrito de la compra]]'' *2003 ''[[My Life Without Me]]'' (Mi vida sin mí) *1998 ''[[A los que aman]]'' *1996 ''[[Things I Never Told You]]'' (Cosas que nunca te dije) *1989 ''[[Demasiado viejo para morir joven]]'' *1984 ''[[Mira y verás]]'' == Awards == '''[[Goya Awards]]''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=August 2011}} [[File:James Albert.jpg|right|thumb|250px|James Albery]]'''James Albery''' (4 May 1838 – 15 August 1889) was an English [[dramatist]].
==Life and career== Albery was born in London. On leaving school Albery entered an architect's office, and started to write plays. His [[farce]] ''A Pretty Piece of Chiselling'' was given its first production by the Ingoldsby Club in 1864. After some failures, his adaptation, ''Dr Davy'', was produced at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London]] (1866). His most successful piece, ''Two Roses'', a comedy, was produced at the [[Vaudeville Theatre]] in 1870, in which [[Sir Henry Irving]] made one of his earliest London successes as Digby Grant.<ref name=EB1911/> The production ran for 300 performances.
Albery was the author of a large number of other plays and adaptations, including ''Coquettes'' (1870); ''Pickwick'', a four-act drama (based on [[Dickens]]'s ''[[The Pickwick Papers]]'' (1871); ''Pink Dominos'' (1877), a [[farce]] that ran for an extremely successful 555 performances and was one of a series of adaptations from the French which he made for the [[Criterion Theatre]], where his wife, the actress Mary Moore (who after his death became Lady [[Charles Wyndham (actor)|Charles Wyndham]] (1861—1931)), played the leading parts; ''Jingle'' (a farcical version of ''Pickwick''), produced at the Lyceum in 1878;<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911|wstitle=Albery, James|inline=1}}</ref> and ''Oriana'' (with music by [[Frederic Clay]]).
His one-act [[operetta]], ''[[The Spectre Knight]]'', with music by [[Alfred Cellier]], ran as a companion piece to [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s ''[[The Sorcerer]]'' and then ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'' at the [[Opera Comique]] in 1878 and on tour. He also wrote the farce ''Brighton'' (1888) among other later plays. Albery also wrote a book called ''Where's the Cat?'' in 1880.
Albery's and Moore's son was [[Bronson Albery]] (1881-1971), a theatre director, after whom the Albery Theatre is named. He wrote this epitaph for himself: "He slept beneath the moon/He basked beneath the sun;/He lived a life of going-to-do,/And died with nothing done."<ref>{{cite book|title=Osmania Veterinarian|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4LpYAAAAYAAJ|year=1954|publisher=Osmania University|page=52}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *Albery's plays are collected in a two-volume edition at the British Library at 2303 f. 14. *''The Dramatic Works of James Albery'', together with a sketch of his career, correspondence bearing thereon, press notices, casts, etc. 2 Volumes. Peter Davies, London, 1939.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060717010721/http://halhkmusic.com/spectre.html Midis and cast list for ''The Spectre Knight''] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130405194343/http://littlecalamity.tripod.com/Quotes/L.html Epitaph quotation] *{{worldcat id|lccn-n82-157829}}
{{Authority control}}
